newsitem.title: USA: Laszlo Birinyi sees Dow hitting 8000 - Barron's.
newsitem.headline: Laszlo Birinyi sees Dow hitting 8000 - Barron's.

text.p: Market analyst Laszlo Birinyi, the president of Birinyi Associates, told Barron's he believes the Dow Jones Industrial Average will hit 8000 in 1997 before ending the year at 7750.
A week after the Dow hit the 7000 plateau, Birinyi's projection for 1997 would translate into a 20 percent advance.

Birinyi, whose firm is based in Greenwich, Conn., said he relies heavily on an indicator called "money flows" that he developed to figure out whether there's more buying or selling pressure on the overall market and on individual stocks.

Birinyi calculates whether trading volume on balance occurred on downticks or on upticks, Barron's explained. A higher volume of trades on upticks is bullish, while a higher volume of trades on downticks is bearish.
For individual stocks and entire indexes, Birinyi sums up each day's money flow using both block trades of 10,000 shares or more and smaller trades, the publication reported.
His research of late has shown that money continues to flow strongly into the Dow stocks, he told Barron's.
"I would argue that money flows on the Dow Jones Industrial Average are the only good indicator of future prices," he said.
While other analysts are urging caution, Birinyi remains optimistic.
"I'm still bullish because I can find a lot more stocks with strong money flows than weak ones," he said.

Birinyi told Barron's that he stocks that look good to him based on money flows are International Business Machines Corp, Motorola Inc, Bristol-Myers Squibb Co, Quaker Oats Co, Compaq Computer Corp, Exxon Corp and Kellogg Co.
A list of stocks that he considers potentially vulnerable are PepsiCo Inc, Nike Inc, Computer Associates International Inc and Monsanto.
